    Novel Conjugated Quinoline–Indoles Compromise Plasmodium falciparum Mitochondrial Function and Show Promising Antimalarial Activity

    • Silvia C. Teguh†∥
      • , 
    • Nectarios Klonis†∥
      • , 
    • Sandra Duffy#
      • , 
    • Leonardo Lucantoni#
      • , 
    • Vicky M. Avery#
      • , 
    • Craig A. Hutton§∥
      • , 
    • Jonathan B. Baell*⊥
      • , and 
    • Leann Tilley*†‡
    View Author Information
    †Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, ‡ARC Centre of Excellence for Coherent X-ray Science, and §School of Chemistry, ∥Bio21 Molecular Science and Biotechnology Institute, The University of Melbourne, Melbourne VIC 3010, Australia
    ⊥ Medicinal Chemistry, Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Science, Parkville VIC 3052, Australia
    # Eskitis Institute for Drug Discovery, Brisbane Innovation Park, Griffith University, Nathan QLD 4111, Australia
    *For L.T.: phone, +61-3-8344-2227; fax, 61-3-9348-1421; E-mail, [email protected]. For J.B.B.: phone, +61-3-9903-9044; E-mail, [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2013, 56, 15, 6200–6215
    Publication Date (Web):July 9, 2013

    SUBJECTS:
    • Antimicrobial agents,

    • Assays
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    A novel class of antimalarial compounds, based on an indol-3-yl linked to the 2-position of a 4-aminoquinoline moiety, shows promising activity against the malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum. Compounds with a quaternary nitrogen on the quinoline show improved activity against the chloroquine-resistant K1 strain. Nonquaternerized 4-aminoquinolines retain significant potency but are relatively less active against the K1 strain. Alkylation of the 4-amino group preferentially improves the activity against the chloroquine-sensitive 3D7 strain. The quinoline-indoles show only weak activity as inhibitors of β-hematin formation, and their activities are only weakly antagonized by a hemoglobinase inhibitor. The compounds appear to dissipate mitochondrial potential as an early event in their antimalarial action and therefore may exert their activity by compromising Plasmodium mitochondrial function. Interestingly, we observed a structural relationship between our compounds and the anticancer and anthelminthic compound, pyrvinium pamoate, which has also been proposed to exert its action via compromising mitochondrial function.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Malaria remains one of the world’s greatest global health challenges. It is estimated that 2.2 billion people live in malaria endemic areas and that the more than 500 million cases of malaria each year result in up to 1.2 million deaths, mostly in young children.(1, 2)Plasmodium falciparum is the causative agent of the most severe form of malaria in humans.
    Drugs have long been a mainstay in the fight against malaria, but their use has been dogged by the development of resistance. While a number of highly successful drugs have been deployed (including quinoline and sulfa drugs), the rapid development and spread of resistance has rendered most of them ineffective in endemic areas.(3) For example until the advent of widespread resistance, the efficacy, long half-life, affordability, and safety profile of chloroquine (3, Figure 1) and other 4-aminoquinolines made this the drug class of choice for combating malaria. 4-Aminoquinolines target the pathway for detoxification of hemoglobin breakdown products.(4-6) Chloroquine, a weak base, is accumulated in the parasite’s acidic digestive vacuole.(7) Here it binds the hematin that is released during hemoglobin degradation and prevents the formation of hemozoin.(8-11) Free hematin has redox and detergent-like activities that are thought to lead to rapid parasite killing.(12-15)
    Unfortunately chloroquine resistance emerged after decades of successful use of this drug and has since reached all malaria-endemic regions.(16) Chloroquine resistance arises as a consequence of mutations in a transporter in the digestive vacuole membrane (called the P. falciparum chloroquine resistance transporter, PfCRT), with the mutant protein mediating the export of the drug out of the vacuole and hence away from its site of action.(17-19) The effectiveness of chloroquine has now declined to the point where it has been officially abandoned in most countries. Nonetheless, newer drugs are too expensive for many and 300–500 million courses of chloroquine are still used each year.(20-23) Other antimalarials such as atovaquone target the mitochondrial cytochrome bc1 complex, while antifolate agents inhibit dihydropteroate synthase or dihydrofolate reductase;(24, 25) however, widespread resistance has reached the level where these drugs have only limited use.(26, 27)
    The World Health Organization currently recommends artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) for treating uncomplicated malaria.(1) ACTs combine an artemisinin derivative, with another longer-acting drug such as lumefantrine, amodiaquine, mefloquine, or sulfadoxine–pyrimethamine, with a different mode of action.(28) Because current antimalarial control in endemic areas is highly dependent on ACTs, recent reports of decreased clinical efficacy of artemisinin and its derivatives are extremely concerning.(29-31)
    Increased efforts in antimalarial drug discovery have been supported by a variety of initiatives such as those involving the Wellcome Trust, Medicines for Malaria Venture, and the Genomic Institute of the Novartis Research Foundation. Some drug companies such as GlaxoSmithKline have screened their corporate libraries and disclosed the structures of antimalarial compounds. These large-scale studies involved screening hundreds of thousands and, in one study, almost two million compounds.(33, 32) These studies have yielded molecules that are potent inhibitors of the growth of blood stage P. falciparum, and preclinical and clinical candidates are emerging.(34-37)
    Nevertheless, there remains a critical need for the development of novel effective antimalarial drugs with efficacy against chloroquine-resistant strains. We recently reported the serendipitous discovery of an indole-linked quinolinium with promising activity against P. falciparum.(38) We now report our investigation into the structure–activity relationships (SAR) of this compound class. We have determined antimalarial activities against chloroquine-sensitive and chloroquine-resistant strains and investigated the mechanism of action.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    We previously identified an N-acetylated analogue of quinolinium 1a (Scheme 1, Table 1) from a high throughput screen (HTS) as having antimalarial activity.(38) Subsequent synthetic studies revealed that the N-acetyl group of the HTS hit could be removed without loss of activity (Teguh, Hutton, Baell, unpublished data). This compound, 1a, represents a better starting point for SAR elaboration as we foresaw the N-acyl group as being potentially reactive. The origin of the acetylated compound was not recorded in prior literature, and no synthetic route was available.(38) We found that the synthetic route shown in Scheme 1, adapted from some related synthetic manipulations, served as a suitable basis for most of the desired SAR probes of 1a.(39-41) This involves acetylation of the 4-amino group and then ring N-methylation of 4-aminoquinaldine (6) to give 7 then 8, respectively, followed by a one-pot condensation with an aryl aldehyde (9, in the presence of 2 equiv of piperidine) that, in most cases, simultaneously leads to the deacetylation of the resulting conjugate to give final products 1a–h. Most 4-aminoquinaldine and aryl aldehyde precursors were obtained commercially. Otherwise, they were synthesized from the corresponding 4-chloroquinaldine.(42) The likely mechanism is shown in Scheme 2, with the key step involving attack of a reactive quaternary Schiff’s base (formed through condensation of piperidine with aryl aldehyde) with the carbanion of the acetylated 4-aminoquinaldine (for review, see ref 43). Using ethanol as the solvent for the condensation reaction, as suggested in the literature for related systems, resulted in lower than expected yields (20–40%).(39) We attributed this to premature loss of the N-acetyl group before condensation, either through base-assisted solvolysis or through transfer to piperidine (the latter also causing deactivation of piperidine) or a combination of the two. Attempts to replace piperidine with a less nucleophilic base such as triethylamine failed, presumably because it could not form the key quaternary iminium species to allow the reaction to take place. To investigate whether solvolysis was the dominating issue, ethanol was replaced with a solvent which would not attack the N-acetyl group. Acetonitrile was chosen, resulting in consistently improved yields of condensed product (by ∼2-fold), although subsequent treatment with potassium carbonate in methanol was required to then remove the N-acetyl group. Relevant target compounds and intermediates and their yields are listed in Table 1.
    Table 1. Intermediates and Final Compounds and Reaction Yields
    compd no R1R2R3R4R5Yyield (%)noteamethodb
    4  H     * 
       
    5 Me      * 
       
    6aHH     * 
     bMeH    99  
     cH7-Cl     * 
     dCH(CH3)CH2CH2CH2N(Et)2H    69*Scheme 5
       
    7aHH    67  
     bMeH    75̂ 
     cH7-Cl    84̂ 
       
    8aHHMe   82̂ 
     bMeHMe   59̂ 
     cH7-ClMe   32̂ 
     dHHBu   60̂ 
       
    9a   MeHC * 
     b   HHC * 
     c   H6-FC * 
     d   HH[7-N] * 
     e   HH[2-N] * 
       
    1aHHMeMeHC58̂a
     bHHMeHHC57̂a
     cMeHMeMeHC44̂b
     dHHMeH6-FC20̂a
     eHHMeHH[7-N]16̂a
     fHHMeHH[2-N]62̂c
     gH7-ClMeHHC73̂d
     hHHBuHHC59̂c
    a

    The meaning of the symbols: * = literature procedure; ̂ = novel compounds; square brackets [ ] = the nitrogen is replacing the aromatic carbon atom.

    b

    Methods: a = ethanol used as solvent without second step using K2CO3; b = ethanol with second step; c = acetonitrile solvent without second step; d = acetonitrile solvent with second step

    Shortening the synthetic route by obviating the acetylation/deacetylation steps was attempted using 10 (which was readily generated from 6a as shown), but this yielded no desired product in the condensation step (Scheme 3). This is presumably due to the decrease in the acidity of the methyl proton of the quinolinium species 10 relative to that in its activated counterpart 8a, preventing formation of the carbanion. We also targeted the synthesis of nonquaternary salt forms of these compounds, such as the neutral quinoline–indole vinylic conjugate 11a. We initially attempted condensation using our previously successful conditions on nonactivated precursors to see if we could directly obtain 11a, but not unexpectedly (given the proposed mechanism), we only obtained traces of the desired product (Scheme 4). The literature describes a variety of methods to construct related systems. For example, condensation has been catalyzed by Lewis acids such as zinc(II) chloride to give styrene derivatives.(44) Alternatively, the N-methyl group of the quaternary salt in related compounds has been removed after condensation with a strong base such as DABCO and pyridinium chloride.(45, 46) However, none of these methods were successful for synthesizing our compounds (Scheme 4). Instead, we investigated alternative ways to activate quinoline precursor 6a. This was achieved through installation of two Boc groups on the 4-amino group, giving 13, and the reaction was conducted using microwave conditions, as shown in Scheme 5.(47)
    Condensation proceeded with concomitant cleavage of the Boc protecting groups to furnish 11a in an acceptable yield of ∼28%. We also prepared the alkyl-linked derivative 15 via reduction of the double bond of 11a. The conjugated indazole 11b was also synthesized, albeit in low yield, using this approach. Finally, we incorporated a chloroquine-like side chain in these compounds via displacement of the labile halogen in 4 with amine 14, giving desired product 11c using the same microwave-mediated condensation conditions (Scheme 5).

    Antimalarial Activity

    We examined the antimalarial activity of the novel compounds against chloroquine-sensitive and resistant strains (3D7 and K1, respectively) during a 48 h incubation period; Table 2). The selectivity of the compounds for P. falciparum (3D7) compared to mammalian (HEK293) cells was determined using 72 h assays, with the selectivity index (SI) defined as the ratio of the IC50 values (Table 2 and Table S1, Supporting Information). Compound 1a inhibits the growth of the 3D7 strain with an IC50 value of 170 nM, in agreement with previous data for the N-acetylated derivative.(38) Importantly, this compound shows similar activity against the K1 strain (resistance index, RI, of 1.3 compared with 15 for 3) and reasonable selectivity for P. falciparum (selectivity index, SI, of 18).
    Table 2. Growth Inhibition of Chloroquine-Sensitive (3D7) and Chloroquine-Resistant (K1) P. falciparuma and Selectivity Indices against HEK293 Mammalian Cellsb
    Table a

    Determined for 48 h exposure using SYBR Green-I fluorescence method. The ± values, where given, indicate the standard deviations of three individual experiments.

    Table b

    Selectivity index values based on HEK293 and 3D7 P. falciparum viability assays using a 72 h exposure period (see Table S1, Supporting Information, for raw values). n/a: not available.

    Table c

    No activity at the highest concentration tested.

    We first examined the influence of the indole ring and its substituents on antimalarial activity and selectivity. A compound devoid of the indole ring (10) was associated with complete loss of activity against both P. falciparum strains, indicating this is critical to the antimalarial activity of these compounds. A compound without the 2-methyl group in the indole ring (1b) did not affect the activity against the 3D7 strain but resulted in ∼2-fold increase in activity against the K1 strain (RI = 0.6) and a modest improvement in selectivity (SI = 35). Further changes to the indole structure, including replacement of the indole ring with indazole (1f), the 7-aza heterocycle (1e), or the addition of a 6-fluorine substituent (1d), produced relatively small decreases in activity against both parasite strains (typically <3-fold) with the greater potency maintained against the K1 strain (RI = 0.3–0.6). Of interest, while the substitutions in 1d and 1e produced large decreases in selectivity compared with 1b, the selectivity of 1f (SI of 107) was increased by ∼3-fold compared with 1b and ∼6-fold compared with the starting compound, 1a.
    We next examined the influence of the quinolinium group and its substituents. Changing the primary amine substituent on the quinolinium group in 1a to a secondary amine by methylation (1c) was associated with a substantial 7–8-fold reduction in activity against both parasite strains. In contrast, addition of a chlorine group to 1b at the 7-position of the quinoline ring to make the ring more chloroquine-like (1g) produced a more modest 2-fold reduction in activity towards both parasite strains but almost complete loss of selectivity against P. falciparum (SI = 2). Similar trends were evident after extending the alkyl substitution on the quaternary nitrogen (1h).
    Pyrvinium pamoate (2) is a compound with a quinolinium–pyrrole structure (Figure 1) that has previously been reported to show antimalarial activity.(48) We tested the activity of 2 against the 3D7 and K1 strains (Table 2) and found that it showed similar activity to other compounds examined in this study. Its activity in our assays (3D7 IC50 = 140 nM) is significantly less than that reported in a previous HTS analysis(48) (IC50 = 3 nM). This may reflect difference in the technology and drug exposure time (48 h in this study, 96 h in the previous study).
    All the compounds examined above contain a quaternary nitrogen atom in the quinoline ring whose permanent positive charge could potentially cause problems in the passage of compounds across membranes. The quinolines 11a and 11b were prepared lacking this permanent positive charge. Spectrophotometric analysis of 11a indicated a pKa value 9.5, which is similar to that of the quinoline ring of 3 (pKa = 8.5),(7) indicating this represents protonation on the quinoline ring nitrogen (Figure S1, Supporting Information). Compounds 11a and 11b were 2–3-fold less potent than their respective quinolinium counterparts 1b and 1f against the K1 strain but 2–3-fold more active against the 3D7 strain. They also maintain good selectivity against P. falciparum relative to mammalian cells. The indazole ring was common to the two most selective compounds, 1f and 11b, suggesting that this moiety is an important determinant of lower mammalian cytotoxicity. The change from an N-alkylquinolinium to a quinoline ring thus appears to make the compounds more chloroquine-like with respect to their activities toward chloroquine-sensitive and resistant strains, although the RI of the compounds remains superior to that of 3 (2–3 vs 15, respectively). Interestingly, further addition of a chloroquine-like alkylamino side chain to 11a to form 11c produced only a modest (2-fold) increase in activity toward the 3D7 strain (RI ∼3). Because this alkylamino group is expected to enhance accumulation of the compound in the parasite’s digestive vacuole, the site of chloroquine action and location of PfCRT, this suggests that these compounds have a different mode and location of action.
    We also used the quinoline analogues to examine the influence of the aryl linker on antimalarial activity. Saturation of the alkyl linker (compound 15) was associated with a substantial loss of activity against both strains indicating that the extended conjugation of the two ring systems is important for their activity.

    Inhibition of β-Hematin Formation

    Chloroquine and other 4-aminoquinolines are thought to exert their antimalarial activities by targeting the heme detoxification pathway. We were interested in determining whether the novel compounds target the same pathway. Hemozoin formation in vivo is thought to be facilitated by specific parasite-derived lipids.(49-51) In this work, we examined the formation of the synthetic version of hemozoin, β-hematin, in the presence of Nonidet P40 detergent, which is a convenient substitute for the lipid catalysts.(52) Chloroquine inhibited the formation of β-hematin with an IC50 value of 30 μM (Table 3), which is similar to the IC50 values found using other methods of promoting hematin crystallization.(53, 54) Inhibition of β-hematin at micromolar concentrations in vitro can lead to antimalarial activity at nanomolar levels in vivo because 3 accumulates in the acidic parasite digestive vacuole, resulting in high intracellular concentrations of active compound.(55) The test compounds exhibiting the greatest potency with respect to β-hematin inhibition were the quinolinium compounds 1a and 1g (Table 3), which were 10 times less effective than 3 with respect to β-hematin inhibition. The other quinolinium compounds examined (1b and 1f) possessed similar antimalarial activities to 1a and 1g (Table 3) but inhibited β-hematin formation only at millimolar concentrations, indicating little correlation between the antimalarial activity of the compounds and their activities as inhibitors in this assay. Similarly, the quinoline compounds 11a and 11c exhibit only a weak ability to inhibit β-hematin formation. These results suggest the quinoline/quinolinium–indole compounds exert their activity in a manner that is different from that of the 4-aminoquinolines.
    Table 3. Inhibition of the Formation of β-Hematina
    compd no.β-hematin inhibition IC50 (μM)
    1a220 ± 50
    1b1400 ± 300
    1f1500 ± 280
    1g300 ± 120
    11a>4000
    11c1100 ± 190
    330 ± 10
    a

    The ± values, where given, indicate the range of variability between two individual experiments (the values for each experiment are the average of triplicate determinations).

    Effect of Exposure Time on Antimalarial Activity

    We examined the ability of short pulse exposure to the quinoline–indoles to kill P. falciparum. As shown in Table 4, 3 kills trophozoite stage P. falciparum with an IC50 (5 h) value of ∼30 nM, which is similar to its IC50 (48 h) value. Similarly, a 5 h exposure of parasites to the antimalarials, methylene blue and WR99210, inhibits trophozoite growth almost as efficiently as a 48 h exposure time. This indicates that these compounds readily access their targets and exert their cytotoxic effects in a prompt manner and is consistent with them acting on trophozoite stages. The quinoline compound 11c, which has an aminoalkyl-substituted amino group in the quinoline ring, exhibits an IC50 (5 h) value that is only moderately less than its IC50 (48 h) value (Table 4). In contrast, the quinolinium–indoles examined (1a, 1b), as well as 2 showed much larger IC50 (5 h) values compared with their IC50 (48 h) values, and exhibited much broader dose–response profiles (Figure S2A–B,D, Supporting Information). This suggests that they are accumulated more slowly or exert their activities more slowly than the other compounds examined. Only compound 11c exhibits a relatively narrow dose–response profile which is similar to that for 3 (Figure S2C, Supporting Information). This suggests that some aspects of the behavior of this chloroquine–quinoline indole hybrid compound are similar to that of 3.
    Table 4. Growth Inhibition IC50 (5 h) and ALLN Antagonism of Selected Compoundsa
       ALLN antagonismb
    compd no.IC50 (5 h) (μM)IC50 (5 h):IC50 (48 h)0.2 μM ALLN5 μM ALLN
    1a0.73 ± 0.0024.31.0 ± 0.21.7 ± 0.4
    1b1.0 ± 0.351.5 ± 0.53.0 ± 1.7
    11c0.17 ± 0.011.71.6 ± 0.12.6 ± 0.2
    20.51 ± 0.13.61.4 ± 0.051.3 ± 0.4
    methylene blue0.03 ± 0.021.52.1 ± 0.43.20 ± 0.01
    WR992100.0004 ± 0.00020.90.7 ± 0.30.7 ± 0.1
    30.03 ± 0.021.54.0 ± 1.620 ± 8
    a

    Determined using SYBR Green-I fluorescence assays using the chloroquine-sensitive 3D7 strain. The ± values indicate the range of variability between two individual experiments with exception of 3, where n = 6 and ± indicates the standard deviations between the different experiments.

    b

    Defined as the ratios of the drug IC50 values measured in the presence and absence of ALLN after a 5 h exposure. See Figure S2, Supporting Information, for dose–response curves.

    Interaction with the Hemoglobin Degradation Pathway

    We previously demonstrated that short pulse assays of drugs in the presence of the hemoglobinase inhibitor, N-acetyl-l-leucyl-l-leucyl-l-norleucinal (ALLN), can be used to identify drugs whose activities depend on the hemoglobin uptake/degradation pathway.(56) Using a similar assay design, we exposed trophozoite stage parasites to the test compounds in the presence or absence of ALLN for a period of 5 h. The drug and ALLN were then removed and the parasites cultured for a further 43 h before parasite survival was assessed. The degree of ALLN antagonism is defined as the IC50 ratio measured in the presence and absence of ALLN. In control experiments, we found that treatment of parasites with a pulse of ALLN alone at these concentrations did not cause substantive killing of P. falciparum (data not shown).(56)
    Co-treatment of 3 with 0.2 or 5 μM ALLN had a dramatic effect on its efficacy (Table 4), with values for ALLN antagonism of 4 and 20, respectively. This result is consistent with the proposed mechanism of action of 3 requiring the hemoglobin degradation product, hematin.(9, 57) In contrast, the antifolate antimalarials, WR99210 and methylene blue, showed little or no interaction with ALLN (antagonism <3.2). Similarly, the quinoline/quinolinium compounds 1a, 1b, and 11c showed little or no interaction with ALLN (antagonism <3 with 5 μM ALLN), consistent with the suggestion that all these compounds exert their activities by targeting a pathway that is different to 3.

    Gametocytocidal Activity

    We examined the ability of four of the compounds to inhibit the early and late development of the sexual stages of P. falciparum using NF54pfs16, a chloroquine-sensitive recombinant line.(58) Artesunate exhibited potent activity against early and late stage gametocytes under the conditions examined in general agreement with a previous report.(58) The quinoliniums (1a, 1b) and the quinoline (11a) each displayed significant activity against early (stage I–III) gametocytes, with IC50 values only 2–3-fold higher than that observed for 3 (Table 5). Interestingly, the novel compounds all retained some activity against late (IV–V) stage gametocytes, with compound 2 showing very promising activity against this stage. By contrast, chloroquine showed negligible activity against late stage gametocytes, with 100% inhibition reached only at the very high concentration of 60 μM (Table 5).
    Table 5. Inhibition of Early and Late Stage Gametocytesa
    compd no.stage I–III IC50 (μM)bstage IV–V IC50 (μM)c
    1a0.35 ± 0.031.9 ± 0.4
    1b0.3 ± 0.14.0 ± 0.6
    11a0.37 ± 0.021.4 ± 0.1
    20.52 ± 0.010.2 ± 0.1
    30.13 ± 0.01∼60
    artesunate0.019 ± 0.0090.008 ± 0.001
    a

    The ± values indicate the standard deviations of data from two separate experiments, each performed in duplicate.

    b

    Synchronous stage I gametocytes were incubated in the presence of compounds for 72 h. Parasite viability was measured using the gametocyte-specific luciferase activity employing the transgenic P. falciparum NF54pfs16 line.

    c

    Synchronous NF54pfs16 stage IV gametocytes were incubated for 72 h in standard culture conditions followed by addition of MitoTracker Red CM-H2Xros and analyzed using an Acapella-based script for viability.

    Effect on Mitochondrial Phenotype

    It has been suggested that 2 exerts its effect by interfering with normal mitochondrial function.(59) We therefore examined the effect of the test compounds on mitochondrial phenotype in trophozoite stage parasites. For these assays, the parasites were incubated with test compounds for 0.5 h before a 5 min coincubation with the fluorescent mitochondrial reporter, MitoTracker Red CMX-Ros. The MitoTracker accumulates in mitochondria with an intact membrane potential, allowing the visualization and classification of mitochondrial phenotypes by fluorescence microscopy. Untreated trophozoites show reticular mitochondria as expected (Figure S3A, Supporting Information).(60) We identified two additional phenotypes in treated cells: (i) cells with a condensed (nonreticular) pattern of MitoTracker labeling indicating a perturbation of mitochondrial morphology without complete loss of membrane potential (Supporting Information, Figure S3B), and (ii) cells with no mitochondrial staining indicating the membrane potential was completely dissipated (Supporting Information, Figure S3C). For the purpose of quantitation, we classified parasites containing either the redistributed or dissipated phenotypes as abnormal mitochondrial phenotypes.
    As shown in Table 6, treatment with the ionophore, carbonyl cyanide 3-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP; 20 μM), produced abnormal mitochondrial phenotypes in most of the cells. All the quinoline-type compounds examined produced abnormal mitochondrial phenotypes at the concentrations examined (Table 6). To ascertain to what extent these abnormal phenotypes reflected the primary mechanism of action of the drugs rather than secondary consequences of drug action (e.g., cell death), we determined parasite viability following the 0.5 h drug pulse by quantitating the parasitemia in the cycle following the pulse.(56) The fraction of parasites treated with the quinoline 11a that exhibited abnormal morphology was similar to the fraction of nonviable parasites across the concentration range examined (Table 6). The fraction of parasites treated with the quinoliniums (1a, 1b, and 2) that exhibited abnormal mitochondrial morphology was similar to or greater than the fraction of unviable parasites over all the concentrations examined (Table 6). In contrast, treatment with 3 or WR99210, which do not exert their antimalarial activity by targeting the mitochondria, results in only a small fraction (<10%) of parasites with abnormal mitochondria even at drug concentrations producing 85% unviable parasites. These results indicate that the quinoline/quinolinium compounds can perturb the mitochondrial phenotype in P. falciparum and suggest that their primary mechanism of action may be to disrupt normal mitochondrial function.
    Table 6. Correlation of Effects of Compounds on Mitochondrial Morphology with Growth Inhibition of Mid to Late Stage Trophozoites (3D7 Strain)a
    compd no.concentration (μM)% nonviable parasites (normalized to “no drug” control)% abnormal mitochondria (normalized to “no drug” control)
    1a1586 ± 499 ± 1
     566 ± 0.597 ± 3
     1.742 ± 186 ± 3
     0.5618 ± 843 ± 3
       
    1b1581 ± 6100 ± 0
     373 ± 1391 ± 2

    a

    Parasite viability measurements performed by flow cytometry using SYTO 61. Mitochondrial morphology quantitated using MitoTracker Red-CMXRos as described in text. The ± values indicate the range of variability between two individual experiments with ≥100 parasites counted for each individual experiment.

    b

    For each of these results, the experiment was performed once.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The development of resistance to chloroquine necessitates sustained efforts to develop new drugs that target alternative pathways or somehow evade the chloroquine resistance mechanism. In this work, we have examined quinoline–indoles as a novel class of antimalarial compounds. A related compound, the FDA-approved anthelminthic, pyrvinium pamoate, was identified in a high throughput screen as possessing potent antimalarial activity but was not pursued due to reports of poor oral bioavailability. Pyrvinium pamoate has activity against another apicomplexan parasite, Cryptosporidium parvum, and also possesses anticancer activity.(48, 61-63) The molecular basis of the activity of pyrvinium pamoate is not clear, but it has been suggested to interfere with glucose absorption or to inhibit mitochondrial NADH–fumarate reductase.(59, 64)
    In this work, we established an efficient route for the synthesis of arylethene-linked 4-aminoquinolines and generated a series of compounds for SAR studies. Many of the compounds examined possess a quaternary amino group in the quinoline ring, leading to a permanent positive charge. It is interesting to consider how these quinolinium compounds might cross membranes. We found the quinoliniums are much less potent when parasites were exposed for only a short period, which is consistent with a slow rate of uptake of these compounds. However, it is known that delocalization of a net positive charge can restore membrane permeability.(65) In fact, there are known delocalized cationic compounds that not only have potent cell-based activity but are orally available.(66) In the case of pyrvinium pamoate, there has been discussion as to whether the poor oral availability is a property of pyrvinium itself or of the pamoate counterion, and it is not clear whether this is due to poor solubility or some effect on metabolism within the gastrointestinal tract, or a combination of the two.(67-70) One concern with positively charged conjugated aromatics is the potential for toxicity, for example, through interference with DNA.(71) It was therefore significant that we discovered that tertiary amino compounds retained substantial activity, as this broadens development options.
    Given their structural similarity to quinoline antimalarials, we considered the possibility that the novel quinoline–indoles might exert their antimalarial activity in a manner similar to chloroquine. Chloroquine and other 4-aminoquinolines accumulate in the parasite’s digestive vacuole, where they bind to hematin generated during hemoglobin digestion and inhibit its sequestration into hemozoin. The ability of compounds to inhibit the formation of β-hematin (the synthetic equivalent of hemozoin) is frequently used to identify compounds that target the same pathway. The novel quinoline–indoles possess only poor activity in this assay, which is consistent with previous studies showing that 7-chloro derivatization of 4-aminoquinolines is needed for efficient inhibition of β-hematin formation.(72, 73) However, in vitro inhibition of β-hematin formation does not always reliably correlate with activity in cellular assays,(74) therefore we were interested to develop an alternative assay that could be used to determine if the novel compounds target the heme detoxification pathway.
    Inhibition of hemoglobin degradation would be expected to slow hematin production and thus antagonize the action of compounds that target this pathway. For example, the aspartic protease inhibitor, Ro40-4388, has been shown to antagonize the action of chloroquine, which is consistent with a role for aspartic proteases in hemoglobin digestion and hematin production.(75, 76) ALLN has been shown to inhibit falcipain hemoglobinases, thereby blocking digestion and leading to an accumulation of hemoglobin in the digestive vacuole.(77) We have shown recently that ALLN is highly antagonistic with artemisinin, indicating that hemoglobin degradation and downstream hematin production is needed for artemisinin action.(56) Previous studies have failed to detect antagonism between the activities of ALLN and chloroquine, but this is likely due to technical difficulties associated with conducting the assay over the complete intraerythrocytic life cycle, given that cysteine protease inhibitors also inhibit other processes such as rupture and reinvasion.(75, 77)
    In this work, in an effort to focus on effects on the hemoglobin degradation pathway and the downstream hematin detoxification pathway, we developed an assay in which trophozoite stage parasites were exposed to test compounds in the presence or absence of the protease inhibitor for a pulse of 5 h. We found that ALLN is highly antagonistic to the action of chloroquine in this assay. By contrast, we observed no interaction of ALLN with WR99210, consistent with the fact that this compound kills P. falciparum by targeting dihydrofolate reductase.(78) The novel quinoline–indoles showed only very limited interaction with ALLN. This indicates that their main mechanism of action does not rely on the production of hematin in the hemoglobin degradation pathway.
    Chloroquine resistance arises as a consequence of mutations in PfCRT that enable export of the drug out of the vacuole, away from the site of action.(19) The quaternary aminoquinolinium–indoles were on average significantly more active against the chloroquine resistant strain, K1, than against the chloroquine sensitive strain, 3D7. The tertiary amino quinoline–indoles showed a modestly lower activity against the chloroquine resistant strain, which may indicate that these compounds can target sites within and outside the digestive vacuole, however, the resistance index is much lower than for chloroquine, again suggesting that the main site of action is outside the digestive vacuole.
    Efforts to achieve malaria elimination will need to incorporate therapies that block gametocyte development and thus the transmission of P. falciparum sexual stage parasites to mosquito vectors. However, gametocytes are nonreplicating and, while they retain an active tricarboxylic acid cycle,(79) some other metabolic processes are down-regulated. For example hemoglobin digestion is completed by stage IV, which makes late stages more resistant to the activities of many blood schizonticides.(58, 80-83) It is therefore of interest that the novel quinoline–indoles exhibited good activity against stage I–III gametocytes and retained some activity against late stage gametocytes. Again, this is consistent with the suggestion that these drugs target a different pathway to chloroquine.
    It has recently been proposed that pyrvinium pamoate exerts its anthelminthic activity and anticancer effects (under hypoxic conditions) by inhibiting NADH–fumarate reductase activity.(59) This system is thought to contribute to the maintenance of the mitochondrial potential in helminths.(84)P. falciparum has also been suggested to have an electron transport chain-independent pathway for maintaining mitochondrial potential but does not appear to contain fumarate reductase.(85) In this work, we found that the quinoline–indoles disrupt mitochondrial potential at concentrations similar to or even lower than the concentrations that lead to parasite killing. While further work is needed to confirm the mitochondrion as the site of action, this work strongly supports a mode of action targeting this site.
    In conclusion, we have characterized a set of novel quinoline–indoles with activity against chloroquine-resistant malaria parasites. We show that the quinolyl quaternary ring nitrogen atom is not needed for antimalarial activity, which presents alternative development options should the quinolinium system be found to be associated with bioavailability or toxicity issues. The compounds appear to operate by a mechanism of action that is distinct from chloroquine and likely target mitochondrial function.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Parasites

    3D7 is a chloroquine-sensitive strain and K1 is a chloroquine-resistant strain of P. falciparum.(86, 87)P. falciparum-infected RBCs were typically cultured at 3% hematocrit in medium containing 4% human serum and 0.5% AlbuMAX in RPMI 1640 supplemented with hypoxanthine and glutamate as described previously(88) using blood donated by the Red Cross Blood Service in Melbourne or Brisbane.

    Assessment of Antimalarial Activity

    Initial screening for antimalarial activity employed a high throughput imaging assay (50 μL assay volume, 2–3% parasitemia, 0.3% hematocrit in 384-well format). Parasite replication after 72 h incubation was imaged using the DNA-intercalating dye 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) coupled with a PerkinElmer OPERA high throughput imaging system and automated image analysis.(89) For further analysis, parasites were plated at 1% parasitemia (100 μL assay volume, 2% hematocrit) in 96-well flat-bottom wells and different concentrations of the compounds were added as serial dilutions from concentrated stocks in methanol or DMSO. The final solvent concentration was less than 0.1%. For standard drug assays, sorbitol-treated ring stage parasites were incubated with the drugs for 48 h. Growth curves based on the uptake of SYBR Green-I were obtained in triplicate, and the concentration of compound required to produce 50% inhibition of growth (IC50) was determined.(90) The resistance index (RI) was used as a measure of the relative sensitivity of the 3D7 strain (IC50(K1)/IC50(3D7)). The selectivity index (SI) was used as measure of the sensitivity of P. falciparum compared with a mammalian cell line (IC50(HEK)/IC50(3D7) and was calculated using the data from 72 h assays. For pulse assays, trophozoite stage parasites were subjected to 0.5 or 5 h exposure to drugs, washed 3 times with 200 μL complete medium before being returned to culture, and analyzed by SYBR Green-I accumulation in the parasite cycle following the drug pulse (24–48 h later). In some experiments (0.5 h pulse assays), growth rates were verified using flow cytometry following labeling with the nucleic acid-binding fluorescent dye SYTO 61 (Invitrogen).(91)
    Parasite viability following each 0.5 h drug exposure was determined by washing the drug-treated cells in complete medium and returning to culture and quantitating the parasitemia in the cycle following the drug pulse by flow cytometry using SYTO 61 staining.(56)

    Gametocyte Inhibition Assays

    NF54pfs16 transgenic parasites were maintained in asexual culture as per standard conditions apart from the following adaptations.(87) Transgenic parasites were maintained in blasticidin (2 μg/mL) in culture media consisting of RPMI with 10 mM HEPES, 25 μg/mL hypoxanthine, 5% pooled human male AB serum, and 0.25% AlbuMax II, and parasitemia was maintained at between 0.5 and 4%. Gametocytogenesis was induced by a drop in hematocrit, increase in ring stage parasitemia and the presence of RBC lysate. After one complete asexual cycle, spontaneously generated gametocytes from previous stress cycles were removed by MACS (Miltenyi Biotec) column technology, resulting in a ring stage culture containing both sexually committed and noncommitted parasites from the single induction cycle. Asexual parasites were killed by treatment with 50 mM N-acetyl glucosamine (NAG).
    Compounds for gametocyte inhibition assays were diluted in DMSO and the assays performed in either duplicate or triplicate point (n = 2). For the early stage luciferase assay, 5 μL of diluted compound was dispensed into 384-well white plates (Perkin-Elmer Culture Plate), and 45 μL of cultures on day 1 of gametocytogenesis at 10% parasitemia and 0.5% hematocrit were added per well. Plates were incubated for 72 h using standard culture conditions, then luciferase activity was determined using a MicroBeta Trilux multidetector luminometer employing the Steadylite Plus luminescence reporter gene assay system (PerkinElmer). For the late stage gametocyte inhibition assay, stage IV gametocytes were purified using MACS columns, then 5 μL of diluted compound was dispensed into 384-well imaging plates and 45 μL of cultures at 10% gametocytemia and 0.1% hematocrit added per well. Plates were incubated for 72 h using standard culture conditions followed by addition of MitoTracker Red CM-H2Xros. The plates were incubated overnight and imaged on the PerkinElmer Opera High Throughput confocal imaging system. The images were analyzed using an Acapella-based script to determine the number of viable parasites. In both assays, 0.4% DMSO and 5 μM puromycin, a nonspecific protein synthesis inhibitor, were used as the in-plate negative and positive controls, respectively. Chloroquine and artesunate were also used as reference inhibitors. The number of viable parasites was determined for each well and the information expressed as % inhibition relative to the controls. IC50 values were determined using Prism v.4.0 by fitting a sigmoidal dose response (variable slope) curve using nonlinear regression.

    Protease Inhibitors Interactions

    In a protocol modified from a previous report(56) synchronized early to mid trophozoite stage 3D7 parasites (10 h window) were cultured for 5 h in 96-well flat-bottom plates in the presence of antimalarial compounds and the presence or absence of ALLN and then for a further 43 h without drugs. Growth inhibition curves were measured using the SYBR Green-I assay. ALLN antagonism is defined as the ratio of IC50 values measured in the presence and absence of ALLN.

    Mammalian Cell Cytotoxicity Assay

    Compounds were added to Falcon 384-well black/clear tissue-treated plates containing 3000 adherent HEK293 cells/well in an assay volume of 45 μL. The plates were incubated for 72 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2. After incubation, the supernatant from the plates was removed and 40 μL of 10% Alamar Blue added to each well before incubating for another 5–6 h. Fluorescence (535 nm excitation, 590 nm emission) was measured using a VICTOR II, PerkinElmer spectrometer.(92) The % inhibition was calculated using DMSO and 10 μM puromycin controls and IC50 values calculated using Prism v.4.0. The selectivity index (SI) was used as measure of the degree to which the drugs exhibited sensitivity toward P. falciparum (IC50(HEK293)/IC50(3D7).

    β-Hematin Formation Inhibition Assay

    The formation of β-hematin in the presence of Nonidet P40 detergent was assessed using modifications of previously described methods.(52, 93) Compounds were serially diluted (in 96-V bottom plate format) and mixed with 100 μM porcine hematin/FP(IX) (Sigma; from a fresh stock in 50 mM NaOH) in 30 μM Nonidet P40 in 2 M sodium acetate, pH 5.0) to a total volume of 150 μL per well. The samples were incubated for 24 h at 37 °C with gentle rocking. Following the incubation, the plates were centrifuged and the pellets resuspended in 25 mM phosphate, pH 7.0, 1% SDS at room temperature overnight. The mixture was pelleted and dissolved in 0.1 M NaOH in 1% SDS for spectrophotometric analysis.(93)

    Assay of Mitochondrial Potential

    Trophozoite-stage parasites (0.5% hematocrit, 10% parasitemia) were preincubated with experimental compounds for 30 min, then incubated with MitoTracker Red CMXRos (25 nM) for 5 min before being washed with serum-free RPMI. The cells were immobilized on closed iBidi 8-well μ-chambers slides coated with conconavalin A (0.5 mg/mL) and imaged using a Delta Vision DV Elite (restorative widefield deconvolution imaging system, Applied Precision). Images were collected at 25 °C, within 1.5 h after preparation using a 100× objective (1.4NA) and TRITC filter settings (excitation 542 nm, emission 594 nm), with consistent brightness setting. For each sample, a series of z-sections (0.5 μm spacing) of random fields was collected, deconvolved, and converted to average projections. The images were processed using ImageJ software, employing 100–2000 brightness levels for the fluorescence images and 100–500 levels for the bright-field images. The mitochondrial phenotype of the population was quantitated using a minimum of 100 randomly selected parasites and classified as normal (reticulated) or abnormal (nonreticulated or dissipated) as described in the text. Data were normalized relative to the untreated sample.

    Chemistry

    Most 4-aminoquinaldines and indole-3-aldehydes were obtained commercially from suppliers including Sigma-Aldrich, Alfa-Aesar, Apollo Scientific, and Combi-blocks. Pyrvinium pamoate and chloroquine were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used for biological assays without further purification. Final compounds for biological testing are all ≥95% pure as determined by LC-MS (analytical HPLC), HRMS, and 1H NMR. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were mostly recorded and analyzed on Bruker NMR spectrometer (300 and 400 MHz), and a minority of samples were run on Varian 400 MHz spectrometer. NMR chemical shifts are reported in ppm, and coupling constants (J) are signals are reported using the current conventions: s = singlet, sbr = broad singlet, dbr = broad doublet, d = doublet, dd = doublet of doublets, t = triplet, q = quartet, m = multiplet.
    Mass spectrometric analyses were performed on five different instruments. All compounds were dissolved in appropriate solvent and diluted in acetonitrile. For high resolution mass spectroscopy (batch HRMSa) run on an Agilent 6220 ESI-TOF LC-MS mass spectrometer, the typical conditions were: ESI, positive ionization mode; drying gas flow, 7 L/min; nebulizer, 35 psi; drying gas temperature, 325 °C; Vcap, 4 kV; fragmentor, 100 V; skimmer, 65 V; OCT RFV, 750 V. Another batch of high resolution mass spectroscopy (HRMSb) was performed on an Agilent 6224 TOF LC/MS coupled to an Agilent 1290 Infinity LC. The typical conditions were: ESI; drying gas flow, 11 L/min; nebulizer pressure, 45 psi; drying gas temperature, 325 °C. Voltages: capillary, 4000 V; fragmentor, 160 V; skimmer, 65 V; octapole RF, 750 V; scan range, 100–1500 m/z; positive ion mode internal reference ions, m/z 121.050873 and 922.009798. LC conditions: Agilent Zorbax SB-C18 Rapid Resolution HT (2.1 mm × 50 mm, 1.8 mm column), 30 °C; sample (5 mL) was eluted using a binary gradient (solvent A, 0.1% aq HCO2H; solvent B, 0.1% HCO2H in CH3CN; 5–100% B [3.5 min], 0.5 mL/min). Most analytical HPLC-MS data (i.e., LC-MSa), as well as prep-HPLC, were obtained using Waters system: ZQ 3100 mass detector for LC-MS; Waters 2545 pump, Waters SFO system fluidics organizer, Waters 2996 diode array detector, and Waters 2767 sample manager; with XBridge TM C18 column, 5 μm, 4.6 mm × 100 mm; injection volume, 10 μL; solvent A, water 0.1% formic acid; solvent B, acetonitrile 0.1% formic acid; gradient, 10–100% B over 10 min; flow rate, 1.5 mL/min; detection, 100–600 nm; single-quadrupole ion source, positive ionization mode; source temp, 150 °C; desolvation temp, 350 °C; detection, ion counting; capillary (kV) 3.00; cone, 30 V; extractor, 3 V; RFV, 0.1 V; scan range, 100–1000 amu; scan time, 0.5 s; acquisition time, 10 min; gas flow, desolvation L/h, 650; cone L/h, 100. A small number of HPLC-MS samples (LC-MSb) were taken by Finnigan LCQ Advantage Max, with Finnigan Surveyor LC pump, Finnigan Surveyor autosampler, and Finnigan Surveyor PDA detector. Typical conditions were: reverse phase HPLC analysis; Gemini 3 μ C18 20 mm × 4.0 mm 110A column; injection volume, 10 μL; solvent A, water 0.1% formic acid; solvent B, acetonitrile 0.1% formic acid; gradient, 10–100% B over 10 min; detection, 100–600 nm; ion source, ion trap; ion mode, ES positive; temp, 300 °C; capillary V, 25; detection, ion counting; scan range, 80–1000A mu; scan time, 0.2 s. Some other HPLC-MS samples (LC-MSc) were run using Agilent HPLC/MS 1220/6120 system, with Agilent 6100 series, Single Quad LC/MS, 1200 series HPLC, 1200 series G1311A quaternary pump, 1200 series G1314B variable wavelength detector. Typical conditions were: reverse phase HPLC analysis; column, Luna C8(2) 5μ 50 mm × 4.6 mm 100A; temperature, 30 °C; injection volume, 5 μL; solvent A, water 0.1% formic acid; solvent B, acetonitrile 0.1% formic acid with gradient 5–100% B over 10 min; detection, 254 or 214 nm; ion source, quadrupole; ion mode, multimode-ES; drying gas temp, 300 °C, vaporizer temperature, 200 °C; capillary voltage, 2000 V (positive), 4000 V (negative); scan range, 100–1000; step size, 0.1 s; acquisition time, 10 min.

    General Procedure A: Condensation of 4-Acetamido-1,2-dimethylquinolinium Compounds with Aryl Aldehydes, Followed by N-Acetyl Solvolysis.(39)

    4-Acetamido-1,2-dimethylquinolinium adduct (0.58 mmol), aryl aldehyde (0.58 mmol, 1 equiv), and piperidine (1.2 mmol, 2 equiv) were dissolved in ethanol or acetonitrile (3.0 mL) and heated at reflux for 24–30 h. The precipitate was isolated by vacuum filtration and triturated with ∼40% methanol (v/v), followed by ethyl acetate, to afford pure conjugated amino compounds. For some reactions in which the solvolysis of the N-acetyl groups was not achieved in one pot, the powder was further dissolved in methanol (∼1.0 mL), treated with a catalytic amount of potassium carbonate, and heated at reflux for an extra 4 h. The precipitate was isolated by filtration and washed with water and then dried to give pure amino products.

    General Procedure B: Acetylation of 4-Amino-2-methylquinolines.(40)

    The appropriate quinoline (28 mmol) and acetic anhydride (0.34 equiv) was dissolved in 8 equiv of pyridine, and the solution was heated at reflux for 6 h. The bulk of the solvent was then removed by rotatory evaporation; the remaining solution was then cooled by ice–water and made alkaline by treatment with aqueous ammonia (pH ∼10). The product was extracted with ethyl acetate and dried in vacuo.

    General Procedure C: Quinolinyl Ring Nitrogen N-Alkylation.(41)

    The appropriate quinoline (3.3 mmol) and alkyl halide (6.6 mmol, 4 equiv) was heated at reflux in acetonitrile (13 mL) for 24 h. The precipitate was isolated by vacuum filtration, washed with ethyl acetate, and dried in vacuo.

    General Procedure D: Condensation between Neutral 4-Aminoquinaldine Compounds and Aryl Aldehydes.(47)

    The appropriate quinaldine (1.6 mmol) and the corresponding indole-3-carboxaldehydes 1.6 mmol, 1 equiv) were suspended in acetonitrile (2.0 mL), and piperidine (15 mol %) was added. The reaction mixture was then heated in microwave reactor to 150–160 °C for 2–5 h. Removal of solvent in vacuo and trituration with dichloromethane afforded the product.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-methyl-2-(2-(2-methyl-3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1a)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as bright-orange powder (58% yield), mp > 250 °C, using 8a as the quinolinium species and 9a as the aryl aldehyde and ethanol as the solvent. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 11.85 (sbr, 1H, indole-NH), 8.55 (sbr, 2H, NH2), 8.42 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.18 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.05–7.98 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.76 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 7.71 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.42 (dd, 1H, ArH), 7.27–7.11 (m, 3H), 7.21 (d, J = 15.2 Hz, 1H, C═CH), 4.13 (s, 3H, N-CH3), 2.62 (s, 3H, indole-CH3). 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 155.6, 155.1, 142.6, 140.0, 136.2, 134.9, 133.9, 125.5, 125.4, 123.8, 122.1, 121.0, 119.7, 118.5, 116.7, 112.0, 111.6, 109.5, 99.2, 37.1 (N-CH3), 12.0 (indole-CH3). IR νmax (cm–1) 3200, 1739, 1631, 1597, 1579, 1561, 1530, 1432, 1226, 738. MS (ESI+) m/z 314.2 (M)+. HRMSa (ESI+) C21H20N3+ requires 314.1657, found 314.1651. Elemental analyses: Found, C, 53.9; H, 4.9; N, 8.5; I, 24.1. C21H20N3I requires C, 57.2; H, 4.6; N, 9.5; I, 28.8%.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-methyl-2-(2-(3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1b)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as brick-orange powder (57% yield), mp > 250 °C, using 8a as the quinolinium species and 9b as the aryl aldehyde and ethanol as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.43 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.19 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.09–7.99 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.79 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 7.72 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.52 (dd, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.36 (d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H, C═CH), 7.27–7.23 (m, 3H, ArH), 7.14 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.14 (s, 3H, N-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.0, 155.0, 140.1, 137.3, 135.7, 134.2, 131.3, 125.8, 124.9, 123.9, 122.8, 121.1, 120.0, 118.7, 116.7, 113.7, 113.1, 112.5, 99.5, 37.2 (N-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.5–5.6, m/z 300.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C20H18N3+ requires 300.1508, found 300.1503. Elemental analyses: Found, C, 56.1; H, 4.5; N, 9.8; I, 29.5. C20H18N3I requires C, 56.2; H, 4.3; N, 9.8; I, 29.7%.

    (E)-4-(N-Methylacetamido)-1-methyl-2-(2-(2-methyl-3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (Intermediate to 1c)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as dark red–brown powder (44% yield), mp > 250 °C, using 8b as the quinolinium species and 9a as the aryl aldehyde and ethanol as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.78 (sbr, 1H, indole-NH), 8.54–8.45 (m, 2H, ArH, CH═C), 8.15–8.07 (m, 3H, ArH), 8.01 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.82 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.49–7.46 (m, 1H, ArH), 7.37–7.29 (m, 3H, ArH, C═CH), 4.43 (s, 3H, N+-CH3), 3.40 (sbr, 3H, AcN–CH3), 2.78 (s, 3H, indole 2-CH3), 1.92 (sbr, 3H, C(O)CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.1, m/z 370.2 (M)+.

    (E)-4-(N-Methylamino)-1-methyl-2-(2-(2-methyl-3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1c)

    1c was obtained quantitatively from deacetylation of its acetylated form with K2CO3(cat.) as brown–red powder. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.22 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.87–7.84 (m, 1H, ArH), 7.70–7.64 (m, 3H, ArH, C═CH), 7.34–7.31 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.08–7.05 (m, 2H, ArH), 6.75 (d, J = 15.0 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 6.44 (s, 1H, ArH), 3.78 (s, 3H, N+-CH3), 3.10 (s, 3H, 4NH-CH3), 2.55(s, 3H, 2-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 155.8, 153.7, 142.9, 139.4, 136.2 (2C), 133.5, 125.8, 125.6, 123.0, 122.2, 121.1, 119.8, 118.7, 117.2, 112.6, 111.6, 109.8, 95.6, 37.3 (N+-CH3), 30.2 (4NH-CH3), 12.1 (2-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.7, m/z 328.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C22H22N3+ requires 328.1811, found 328.1813.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-methyl-2-(2-(6-fluoro-3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1d)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as red–orange powder (20% yield), mp > 250 °C, using 8a as the quinolinium species and 9c as the aryl aldehyde and ethanol as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.63 (sbr, 2H, NH2), 8.44 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.21–8.00 (m, 4H, ArH), 7.78–7.70 (m, 2H, ArH, CH═C), 7.39–7.30 (m, 2H, ArH, C═CH), 7.12–7.06 (m, 2H, ArH), 4.13 (s, 3H, N-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 155.9, 154.9, 140.1, 138.3 (d), 135.3, 134.1, 133.3, 125.7, 123.9, 122.0, 121.1 (d), 118.6, 116.8, 113.3, 113.2, 109.2 108.9, 99.5, 99.1 (d), 37.1 (N-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.4–5.5, m/z 318.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C20H17FN3+ requires 318.1409, found 318.1403.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-methyl-2-(2-(7-aza-3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1e)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as bright orange-yellow powder (16% yield), using 8a as the quinolinium species and 9d as the aryl aldehyde and ethanol as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.63 (sbr, 2H, NH2), 8.55 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.47 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.36 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.23–8.18 (m, 2H, ArH), 8.03 (t, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.77–7.71 (m, 2H, ArH, CH═C), 7.41 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H, C═CH), 7.30–7.25 (m, 1H, ArH), 7.11 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.14 (s, 3H, N-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.2, 154.7, 149.5, 144.0, 140.0, 134.9, 134.2, 131.4, 128.5, 125.8, 123.9, 118.7, 117.1, 117.0, 116.7, 115.0, 111.7, 99.8, 37.3 (N-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 4.4–4.6, m/z 301.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C19H17N4+ requires 301.1459, found 301.1454.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-methyl-2-(2-(3aH-indazol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1f)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as light yellow–green powder (62% yield), using 8a as the quinolinium species and 9e as the aryl aldehyde and acetonitrile as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.48 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.26–8.21 (m, 2H), 8.06 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.78–7.73 (m, 2H), 7.66 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.46 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.31 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.17 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.15 (s, 3H, N-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.8, 153.7, 141.5, 140.6, 140.0, 134.5, 132.3, 126.7, 126.1, 124.0, 122.0, 121.0, 120.9, 120.5, 118.7, 116.7, 111.0, 101.1, 37.6 (N-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 4.8–4.9, m/z 301.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C19H17N4+ requires 301.1459, found 301.1454.

    (E)-4-Amino-7-chloro-1-methyl-2-(2-(3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1g)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as dark brick-orange powder after further deacetylation with K2CO3(cat.) (73% yield after 2 steps), using 8c as the quinolinium species and 9b as the aryl aldehyde and acetonitrile as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.40 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.18 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.05–8.00 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.78 (d, J = 15.6 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 7.70 (d, J = 8.1, 1H, ArH), 7.52–7.50 (m, 1H, ArH), 7.23–7.17 (m, 3H, ArH, C═CH), 7.07 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.04 (s, 3H, N-CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 155.6, 155.0, 141.0, 138.7, 138.1, 135.9, 132.5, 126.0, 125.6, 125.1, 122.5, 120.9, 119.8, 118.0, 115.7, 113.2, 112.8, 112.4, 99.7, 37.1 (N-CH3). LC-MSc (ESI+) rt 3.4, m/z 334.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C20H17ClN3+ requires 334.1107, found 334.1109.

    (E)-4-Amino-1-butyl-2-(2-(3aH-indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolinium Iodide (1h)

    According to general procedure A, the title compound was obtained as light-orange powder (59% yield), using 8d as the quinolinium species and 9b as the aryl aldehyde and acetonitrile as the solvent. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.63 (sbr, 2H, NH2), 8.44 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.20 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.03–7.98 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.77 (d, J = 16.5 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 7.71 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.53 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.34–7.22 (m, 3H, ArH, C═CH), 7.14 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.64 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H, N-CH2CH2CH2CH3), 1.90–1.78 (m, 2H, N-CH2CH2CH2CH3), 1.54–1.45 (m, 2H, N-CH2CH2CH2CH3), 0.97 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H, N-CH2CH2CH2CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 156.1, 154.3, 139.2, 137.5, 136.2, 134.4, 131.5, 125.9, 124.9, 124.3, 122.9, 121.1, 119.7, 118.5, 117.0, 113.1, 113.0, 112.7, 99.7, 48.0 (N-CH2), 30.3, 19.3, 13.7 (CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 6.0, m/z 342.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C23H24N3+ requires 342.1973, found 342.1978.

    Synthesis of N,2-Dimethylquinolin-4-amine (6b).(42)

    4-Chloroquinaldine (4, 0.50 g, 2.8 mmol) and 33% methylamine in ethanol (4.0 mL, 40 mmol) were heated at 120 °C for 7 h in a sealed tube using a microwave reactor. The HCl-salt form of the product was separated by vacuum filtration. It was then treated with excess 5 M KOH(aq), and the pure product was refiltered from the aqueous solution and dried. The product was isolated as yellow–white needles in quantitative yield. 1H NMR (300 MHz, (CD3)2CO) δ 7.99 (dd, J = 8.4 Hz 1H, ArH), 7.76 (dd, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.54 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.31 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 6.44 (s, 1H, 4-CH3NH), 6.36 (s, 1H, ArH), 2.99 (dbr, 3H, 4-CH3NH), 2.50 (s, 3H, CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 2.0–2.2, m/z 173.2 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of N-(5-(Diethylamino)pentan-2-yl)-2-methylquinolin-4-amine (6d).(94)

    4-Chloroquinaldine (4, 1.0 g, 5.6 mmol) and 2-amino-5-diethylaminopentane (14, 1.8 g, 5.6 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (0.50 mL) and heated at 220 °C for 8 h in the microwave. The crude oil was then treated with 5 M KOH, extracted with ethyl acetate, and purified by column chromatography with 10% MeOH in DCM (v/v) solvent system. The product was isolated as red–brown oil (1.2 g, 69% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 11.25 (sbr, 1H, NH), 7.88–7.77 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.61 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 6.83 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.19–4.13 (m, 1H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 3.32–3.14 (m, 6H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 2.69 (s, 3H, CH3), 2.01–1.77 (m, 4H, N(CH2CH3)2), 1.41 (d, J = 6.5 Hz, 3H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 1.28 (t, J = 9.0 Hz, 6H, N(CH2CH3)2). 13C NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.12, 149.12, 148.04, 128.87, 128.59, 123.51, 119.45, 117.38, 98.88, 52.48, 48.00, 46.66 (2C, N(CH2CH3)2), 34.46, 25.45, 23.67, 20.15, 11.30 (2C, N(CH2CH3)2). LC-MSb (ESI+) rt 6.6, m/z 300.1 (M + H)+.

    N-(2-Methylquinolin-4-yl)acetamide (7a)

    The title compound was obtained via general procedure B using 4-aminoquinaldine (6a) as light-brown needles (67% yield) mp 161–163 °C (lit. ref mp 163–165 °C).(40)1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.16 (sbr, 1H, NH), 8.03 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.89 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.76 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.68 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.48 (m, 1H, ArH), 2.72 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 2.34 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). MS (ESI+) m/z 201.1 (M + H)+.

    N-Methyl-N-(2-methylquinolin-4-yl)acetamide (7b)

    The title compound was obtained via general procedure B using N,2-dimethylquinolin-4-amine (6b) as brown powder (75% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.92 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.63–7.54 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.40 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.06 (s, 1H, ArH), 3.18 (s, 3H, N(Ac)CH3), 2.61 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 1.63 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 169.5 (C═O), 159.5, 149.0, 148.5, 129.8, 128.9, 126.5, 123.0, 121.5, 120.1, 36.3 (N(Ac)CH3), 24.8, 21.5. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 2.2, m/z 215.4 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C13H14N2O requires 214.1116, found 215.1189 (M + H)+.

    N-(7-Chloro-2-methylquinolin-4-yl)acetamide (7c)

    The title compound was obtained via general procedure B using 7-chloro-4-amino-2-methylquinoline (6c) as pink–brown powder (84% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, (CD3)2CO) δ 9.48 (sbr, 1H, NH), 8.25–8.20 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.91 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.48 (dd, J = 9.0 Hz, 2.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 2.63 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 2.30 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 169.6 (C═O), 161.0, 147.7, 141.8, 136.1, 127.4, 126.6, 121.6, 117.1, 112.3, 25.1, 25.0. LC-MSc (ESI+) rt 2.8, m/z 235.0 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C12H11ClN2O requires 234.0564, found 235.0638 (M + H)+.

    4-Acetamido-N,2-dimethylquinolinium Iodide (8a)

    According to general procedure C, the title compound was obtained using quinoline 7a and methyl iodide, being isolated as brown–white powder, (82% yield) mp >250 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.91 (sbr, 1H, NH), 8.77 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.63 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.49 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.19 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.97 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 4.29 (s, 3H, N-CH3), 2.98 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 2.41 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 171.2 (C═O), 160.2, 148.4, 139.7, 134.6, 127.7, 124.1, 119.0, 118.9, 111.7, 38.8, 25.0, 23.5. IR νmax (cm–1) 3198, 3093, 1718, 1624, 1604, 1580, 1537, 1506, 1344, 1210, 781, 764. MS (ESI+) m/z 215.1 (M)+. HRMS (ESI+) C13H15N2O+ requires 215.1184, found 215.1180.

    1,2-Dimethyl-4-(N-methylacetamido)quinolinium Iodide (8b)

    According to general procedure C, the title compound was obtained using quinoline 7b and methyl iodide, being isolated as brown–yellow powder (59% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.44 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.18 (td, J = 8.8 Hz, 1.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.09 (d, J = 7.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.00 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.91 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 4.61 (s, 3H, N-CH3), 3.56 (s, 3H), 3.34 (s, 3H), 2.18 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 170.1 (C═O), 162.1, 155.9, 140.7, 135.1, 129.3, 125.7, 124.9, 123.9, 119.7, 39.7, 38.0, 23.2, 22.4. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 0.8, m/z 229.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C14H17N2O+ requires 229.1348, found 229.1342.

    4-Acetamido-7-chloro-N,2-dimethylquinolinium Iodide (8c)

    According to general procedure C, the title compound was obtained using quinoline 7c and methyl iodide, being isolated as white–brown powder (32% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.98 (sbr, 1H, NH), 8.80 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.63–8.62 (m, 2H, ArH), 8.08 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 4.26 (s, 3H, N–CH3), 2.96 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 2.39 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 171.1 (C═O), 161.2, 148.4, 140.7, 139.8, 128.2, 126.2, 118.9, 117.7, 112.0, 39.1 (N-CH3), 24.9, 23.5. LC-MSc (ESI+) rt 2.7, m/z 249.2 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C13H14ClN2O+ requires 249.0801, found 249.0795.

    4-Acetamido-N-butyl-2-methylquinolinium Iodide (8d)

    According to general procedure C, the title compound was obtained using quinoline 7a and butyl iodide, being isolated as brown–gray powder (60% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 10.95 (sbr, 1H, NH), 9.54 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.73 (s, 1H, ArH), 8.07–8.01 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.74 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 4.74 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H, NCH2CH2CH2CH3), 3.00 (s, 3H, 2-CH3), 2.75 (s, 3H, C(O)CH3), 1.94–1.86 (m, 2H, NCH2CH2CH2CH3), 1.69–1.59 (m, 2H, NCH2CH2CH2CH3), 1.07 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H, NCH2CH2CH2CH3). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 171.2 (C═O), 159.6, 148.6, 139.0, 134.8, 127.8, 124.4, 119.3, 119.2, 112.1, 50.1, 30.0, 24.9, 22.8, 19.2, 13.5. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 4.5, m/z 257.3 (M)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C16H21N2O+ requires 257.1655, found 257.1652.

    4-Amino-N,2-dimethylquinolinium Iodide (10)

    According to general procedure C, the title compound was obtained using quinoline 6a and methyl iodide, being isolated as purple–brown powder (87% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.76 (sbr, 1H, NH2), 8.44 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.17 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.02 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.73 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 6.73 (s, 1H, ArH), 3.98 (s, 3H, N-CH3), 2.72 (s, 3H, 2-CH3). LC-MSc (ESI+) rt 2.6, m/z 173.2 (M)+.

    2-((E)-2-(1H-Indol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolin-4-amine (11a)

    According to general procedure D, using the diBoc-quinaldine (13) and 9b as the aldehyde, the title compound was isolated as orange–yellow powder (28% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.11 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.99–7.92 (m, 2H, ArH, HC═C), 7.77–7.76 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.68 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.52–7.39 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.22–7.19 (m, 1H, indole-H), 7.05 (d, J = 16.1 Hz, 1H, C═CH), 6.93 (s, 1H, ArH). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 157.5, 154.5, 142.2, 139.2, 134.6, 133.7, 131.2, 126.4, 126.3, 123.9, 123.7, 122.1, 122.0, 121.0, 117.6, 116.2, 114.8, 113.2, 98.3. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.1–5.2, m/z 286.2 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C19H15N3 requires 285.1268, found 286.1340 (M + H)+.

    2-((E)-2-(1H-Indazol-3-yl)vinyl)quinolin-4-amine (11b)

    According to general procedure D, using the diBoc-quinaldine (13) and 9e as the aldehyde, the title compound was isolated as yellow powder (∼5% yield). Note that a precipitate was not formed by trituration with dichloromethane according to the general procedure. Therefore the product was isolated by treating the mixture with 33% HCl(aq) and further treating it with K2CO3(aq) (1 equiv) until pH ∼10, after which a precipitate was formed. 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOD) δ 8.19 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.04 (dd, J = 8.4, 0.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.87 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.83 (d, J = 16.8 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 7.69–7.60 (m, 2H, ArH, C═CH), 7.58 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.49–7.38 (m, 2H, ArH), 7.29 (td, J = 7.9, 0.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.08 (s, 1H, ArH). 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ 157.63, 149.30, 141.43, 140.60, 138.73, 133.94, 131.21, 126.78, 125.98, 123.53, 122.06, 120.98, 120.55, 120.02, 119.75, 115.62, 111.04, 99.00. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.0, m/z 287.2 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C18H14N4 requires 286.1224, found 287.1298 (M + H)+.

    2-((E)-2-(1H-Indol-3-yl)vinyl)-N-(5-(diethylamino)pentan-2-yl)quinolin-4-amine (11c)

    According to general procedure D, using alkylaminoquinaldine (6d) and 9b as the aldehyde, the title compound was isolated as orange solid (20% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.40 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 8.27 (d, J = 16.2 Hz, 1H, HC═C), 8.07 (dd, 1H, indole-H), 7.86–7.76 (m, 3H, ArH), 7.54 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.42–7.39 (m, 1H, indole-H), 7.22–7.14 (m, 3H, ArH, C═CH), 7.08 (s, 1H, ArH), 4.34–4.30 (m, 1H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 3.25–3.03 (m, 6H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 1.99–1.80 (m, 4H, N(CH2CH3)2), 1.47 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H, NHCH(CH3)(CH2)3NEt), 1.30 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 6H, N(CH2CH3)2). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ155.6, 154.0, 139.6, 139.3, 137.2, 134.3, 132.7, 127.1, 126.3, 124.1, 123.7, 122.4, 121.3, 120.3, 117.7, 114.9, 114.0, 113.3, 94.8, 53.0, 50.4, 48.5 (2C), 33.8, 22.2, 20.3, 9.2 (2C). LC-MSb (ESI+) rt 4.1, m/z 427.2 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C28H34N4 requires 426.2796, found 427.2863 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 2-Methyl-N,N-di-tert-butoxycarbonylquinolin-4-amine (13).(95)

    4-Aminoquinaldine (6a, 1.0 g, 6.3 mmol) was stirred with sodium bis(trimethylsilyl)amide (12 mL of 1 M solution in THF, 12 mmol) in dry THF (30 mL) at 0 °C for the first 0.5 h, then di-t-butyl dicarbonate (2.8 g, 13 mmol) was added and the mixture stirred for a further 24 h. Upon reaction completion, the mixture was treated with 25% NH4Cl(aq), extracted with ethyl acetate, and dried. The crude oil was purified by column chromatography with 15% methanol in DCM solvent system to afford pure product as a yellow oil (40% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.09 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.84 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.69 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.53 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.22 (s, 1H, ArH), 2.77 (s, 1H, 2-CH3), 1.37 (s, 18H, NCOO(C(CH3)3)2. 13C NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.2 (2C, C═O), 150.8, 148.8, 144.4, 129.6, 128.8, 126.3, 124.1, 121.7, 121.0, 83.3 (2C, NCOO(C(CH3)3)2), 27.6 (6C, NCOO(C(CH3)3)2), 25.2 (2-CH3). LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 6.6, m/z 359.2 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C20H26N2O4 requires 358.1895, found 359.1968 (M + H)+.

    Synthesis of 2-(2-(1H-Indol-3-yl)ethyl)quinolin-4-amine (15) by Hydrogenation.(96)

    11a (20 mg, 0.13 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (3.0 mL), 10% palladium on charcoal (10 mol %) was added, and the mixture was stirred with constant H2(g) flow for 24–30 h (followed by TLC). The palladium on charcoal was then removed by filtration, and the filtrate was dried in vacuo and purified by HPLC. The product was obtained as light-orange powder (53% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 8.22 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.86 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.76 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.60 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.48 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.32 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.06 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 1H, ArH), 7.01 (s, 1H, ArH), 7.60 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, ArH), 6.58 (s, 1H, ArH), 3.30–3.21 (m, 4H, CH2-CH2). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CD3OD) δ 159.3, 158.7, 141.2, 138.2, 134.5, 128.4, 127.1, 124.1, 123.4, 122.4, 121.2, 119.7, 119.0, 117.0, 113.9, 112.4, 103.0, 36.7, 26.1. LC-MSa (ESI+) rt 5.0, m/z 288.3 (M + H)+. HRMSb (ESI+) C19H17N3 requires 287.1430, found 288.1504 (M + H)+.

    3. 3
      Petersen, I.; Eastman, R.; Lanzer, M. Drug-resistant malaria: molecular mechanisms and implications for public health FEBS Lett. 2011, 585, 1551– 1562
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Drug-resistant malaria: Molecular mechanisms and implications for public health
      Petersen, Ines; Eastman, Richard; Lanzer, Michael
      FEBS Letters (2011), 585 (11), 1551-1562CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Resistance to antimalarial drugs has often threatened malaria elimination efforts and historically has led to the short-term resurgence of malaria incidences and deaths. With concd. malaria eradication efforts currently underway, monitoring drug resistance in clin. settings complemented by in vitro drug susceptibility assays and anal. of resistance markers, becomes crit. to the implementation of an effective antimalarial drug policy. Understanding of the factors, which lead to the development and spread of drug resistance, is necessary to design optimal prevention and treatment strategies. This review attempts to summarize the unique factors presented by malarial parasites that lead to the emergence and spread of drug resistance, and gives an overview of known resistance mechanisms to currently used antimalarial drugs.

      Bray, P. G.; Ward, S. A.; O’Neill, P. M. Quinolines and artemisinin: chemistry, biology and history Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 2005, 295, 3– 38

    7. 7
      Foley, M.; Tilley, L. Quinoline antimalarials: mechanisms of action and resistance and prospects for new agents Pharmacol. Ther. 1998, 79, 55– 87
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Quinoline antimalarials: mechanisms of action and resistance and prospects for new agents
      Foley, Michael; Tilley, Leann
      Pharmacology & Therapeutics (1998), 79 (1), 55-87CODEN: PHTHDT; ISSN:0163-7258. (Elsevier Science Inc.)
      Quinoline-contg. antimalarial drugs, such as chloroquine, quinine and mefloquine, are mainstays of chemotherapy against malaria. The mol. basis of the action of these drugs is not completely understood, but they probably interfere with Hb digestion in the blood stages of the malaria parasite's life cycle. The parasite degrades Hb, in an acidic food vacuole, producing free heme and reactive O species as toxic byproducts. The heme moieties are neutralized by polymn., while the free radical species are detoxified by a vulnerable series of antioxidant mechanisms. Chloroquine, a dibasic drug, is accumulated several thousand-fold in the food vacuole. The high intravacuolar chloroquine concn. is proposed to interfere with the polymn. of heme and/or the detoxification of the reactive O species, effectively killing the parasite with its own metabolic waste. Chloroquine resistance appears to arise as a result of a decreased level of chloroquine uptake, due to an increased vacuolar pH or to changes in a chloroquine importer or receptor. The more lipophilic quinolinemethanol drugs mefloquine and quinine do not appear to be concd. so extensively in the food vacuole and may act on alternative targets in the parasite. Resistance to the quinolinemethanols is thought to involve a plasmodial homolog of P-glycoprotein. As the malaria parasites become increasingly resistant to the quinoline antimalarials, there is an urgent need to understand the mol. mechanisms for drug action and resistance so that novel antimalarial drugs can be designed. A no. of modified quinolines and bisquinoline compds. show some promise in this regard. A review with many refs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXjvFKjs7k%253D&md5=ae2b71af4fd689cfbd496727e28a82a6

      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar
